large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Dentists and What They Do

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, play a counting game, and introduce vocabulary (dentist, tools).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What is one thing a dentist does?
Read for meaning and enjoyment, pausing to practice counting.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recite number words from 1 to 30 in order.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Exercise good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Respond to instructional language.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children practice rote counting from one to twenty using Connecting Cubes as “teeth”.
Ask how many “teeth” in all, and discuss children’s own teeth and experiences.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What book did you choose? What is this book about?
Can you pretend to be a dentist? What is something you will do?
Can you draw a picture of teeth? How many teeth are in your drawing?
Can you write about going to the dentist? What is the first thing you will do there?
How many different shapes are on your page? What shapes are they?
What letter did you make? How did you make it?
What are you building? What materials will you use to build it?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Dentists and What They Do by Liesbet Slegers. Copyright © 2018 by Clavis Publishing Inc., New York. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Clavis Publishing Inc.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Dentists and What They Do

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder make and keep relationships and introduce vocabulary (friendship).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Dentists and What They Do.
Read closely to explore relationships and review counting.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to 5) scattered (Cardinality).
Count the same number of different items to see that the quantity is the same even when the objects are different.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.
Respond to instructional language.
Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts.
Share background knowledge.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to act out the relationship between a dentist and patient.
Help children count the same number of different “tools” and rote count as they “brush their teeth.”
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Why did you choose that book?
Can you pretend to be a dentist? How does a dentist act? Can you show how it feels to be a dentist?
Can you show how you use your fingers for counting to 10? Why are they helpful?
Can you write about how a dentist helps you take care of your teeth?
Can you make a dentist’s office? What colors and shapes will you use?
Can you find something in the room that starts with the same letter sound as dentist?
How many blocks are in what you are building?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Dentists and What They Do by Liesbet Slegers. Copyright © 2018 by Clavis Publishing Inc., New York. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Clavis Publishing Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Dentists and What They Do

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to review counting objects in different orders, play a counting game, and introduce vocabulary (order).
Begin Story Time by revisting Dentists and What They Do and asking the question, What is one thing the boy does when he goes to the dentist?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review counting in different orders.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Count the same number of different items to see that the quantity is the same even when the objects are different.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Respond to instructional language.
Exercise good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to practice counting Connecting Cube “teeth” in various different orders.
Guide children to see that the total number does not change.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How can you count all the objects on that page?
How can you pretend to be a dentist checking someone’s teeth?
If you counted starting from the end, would the number change? Why not?
Can you write about taking care of your teeth?
Can you draw a story about objects being lined up in order?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word tool? Can you think of another word that begins with that sound?
Why did you pick those materials?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Dentists and What They Do by Liesbet Slegers. Copyright © 2018 by Clavis Publishing Inc., New York. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Clavis Publishing Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Keep Your Hands Clean

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Dentists and What They Do

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to play a counting game and introduce vocabulary (scrub, rinse).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Keep Your Hands Clean and Dentists and What They Do.
Read interactively and connect to counting.
Offer an extended play activity.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recite number words from 1 to 30 in order.
Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Respond to instructional language.
Exercise good habits of personal health and hygiene.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Pretend to wash your hands while counting to twenty, and skip a number while counting.
Ask children to raise their hands when they hear the mistake, and identify the number skipped.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do you think about that book?
Pretend to wash your hands very quickly! Now pretend to take your time. Let’s compare. Which way will get your fingers cleaner?
Can you count those objects starting with the last one?
Can you write about the order in which you wash your hands?
Can you use a darker color?
Can you look around the room and find something that starts with the sound t?
How can you make your structure stronger?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Dentists and What They Do by Liesbet Slegers. Copyright © 2018 by Clavis Publishing Inc., New York. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Clavis Publishing Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Dentists and What They Do

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to connect the book to basic economics and to practice counting different items of the same quantity.
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What is one thing you can do to keep your teeth healthy?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on counting.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recite number words from 1 to 30 in order.
Count the same number of different items to see that the quantity is the same even when the objects are different.
Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Respond to instructional language.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.
Write for different purposes.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: How does a dentist help keep you healthy?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What kind of book would you like to read next?
Pretend to be visiting the dentist for the first time. How do you feel?
Here is a set of 28 teeth. If I start counting from the middle, will there still be 28? Let’s check.
Can you write about a visit to the dentist?
Imagine what it looks like in a dentist’s office. Can you draw it?
Choose a name for a dentist. What letter does the dentist’s name start with?
What ideas do you have for building your own doctor or dentist’s office? What do you imagine it will look like?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Dentists and What They Do by Liesbet Slegers. Copyright © 2018 by Clavis Publishing Inc., New York. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Clavis Publishing Inc.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use words to rote count from 1 to 30.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Use effective verbal and nonverbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers/adults.
Practice good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Discuss the roles and responsibilities of family, school, and community helpers.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Use effective verbal and non-verbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers/adults.
Discuss the roles and responsibilities of family, school, and community helpers.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Use effective verbal and non-verbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers/adults.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Practice good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Discuss the roles and responsibilities of family, school, and community helpers.
Use words to rote count from 1 to 30.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Use effective verbal and non-verbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers/adults.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Practice good habits of personal health and hygiene.
Use words to rote count from 1 to 30.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Use effective verbal and non-verbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers/adults.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Discuss the roles and responsibilities of family, school, and community helpers.
